title: Where business gets it wrong with Canberra
text:
Peter Costello, former treasurer and chairman of BOSS publisher Nine, former premiers Anna Bligh, Steve Bracks and Nick Greiner, former cabinet ministers Greg Combet and Helen Coonan, business leaders Tony Shepherd and Jennifer Westacott, and former Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet boss Ian Watt all took part.

Among the recommendations for chief executives and company directors looking to get more bang for their Canberra buck is to view government and opposition MPs as core stakeholders, and to develop consistent relationships with bureaucrats and backbenchers. Meeting with the occasional minister won’t cut it.

“The relationship with the opposition is important for many reasons. The most obvious is that our political cycle means that opposition parties will at some stage be in government – and ruling parties will be in opposition. Another important consideration is that opposition parties can move amendments, stall or stop legislation,” the report concludes.

Andrew Bragg, seen delivering his first speech in the Senate chamber in July, says all MPs want to engage with business and the community. AAP

It notes that backbench and crossbench MPs influence policy and drive outcomes, and suggests that meeting the relevant shadow minister could be the start of a beneficial and lasting relationship.

Lobbyists can handle crisis management when required, but chief executives, chairmen and board members need to manage relationships with key politicians and public servants, guided by government relations consultants.

Andrew Bragg has been on both sides. The one-time Business Council of Australia executive director is an up-and-coming NSW Liberal senator.

He says scheduling meetings in Canberra during sitting weeks has limited utility.

“If there are people in business who want to raise a particular issue, you are far better off doing it in people’s natural habitat, which is in their electorates,” he says. “Canberra is a terrible place to have a meeting when you’re trying to discuss a substantial policy issue beyond slogans.

Advertisement

“In my experience, most business issues are complicated. They usually involve markets. Therefore, trying to have a meeting in between bells and buzzers is nigh on impossible.”

The Korn Ferry report says learning how government works will save time and resources, and deliver better results. Business leaders need to know how the budget cycle works, and understand that political donations won’t equal policy outcomes.

Bragg points to a former Australian Stock Exchange boss as the gold standard.

“Not one person we spoke to thought that donations resulted in influence," says Korn Ferry's Katie Lahey. Paul Jeffers

“The best example I ever saw of an organisation or a person dealing with Canberra was Elmer Funke Kupper,” he says. “He would go to every single meeting, no matter who it was inside the government. It could be a junior Treasury official, it could be the treasurer; he would meet with an adviser to an opposition shadow minister. I think that is the best approach.

“As we have seen in the financial sector, it is very important that non-executive directors, chairs [and] chief executives are fully aware of the expectations of policymakers and the law. Clearly there’s a need for more of that, not less.”

Anika Wells calls the Canberra shuffle “a unique species”.

“If I have prioritised a meeting in a sitting week, it has been a strategic decision based on them sharing priorities with me. Some people will turn up with a brief on how their particular issue or cause impacts in Lilley, with local stats, and you can tell they’ve researched me.

“Other people will turn up and say they’re doing a circuit of all the MPs and hand over a flyer. It’s such a clear tick and flick exercise. That might get you in the door once, but I doubt it will get you in the door again.”

Korn Ferry chairman Katie Lahey says report participants looked back at the Hawke and Howard governments as times when business was brought along effectively in decision-making.

Advertisement

“Two big reforms – the Prices and Income Accord under Hawke, and the GST under Howard – were cited as examples of government and business working well together,” she says.

“The chair or chief executive or organisations that are not engaging productively with government may need to reset their approach.

“This starts with acknowledging that a good relationship with government is important. The CEO and chair must each value the relationship, and the CEO needs to take responsibility for it.”

Lahey has a blunt message on the thorny issue of political donations: “Not one person we spoke to thought that donations resulted in influence. They said donations for policy outcomes is not good government affairs strategy.

“However, attending business forums, or other events where you can meet various industry and government people, is worthwhile.”

Bragg says all MPs want to engage with business and the community, and says all sides should support the democratic process and do policy development.

“My greatest fear in this whole area is that policy formulation is only done by unions, think tanks and public servants,” he says. “That, I think, would be very bad for Australia’s future.”
description: Chief executives and company directors meet with MPs every day, yet many don’t know how to do it effectively. A new guide is designed to change that.
